articles.description:
Posted by Kent Walker, President, Global Affairs & Chief Legal Officer, Google & Alphabet and Royal Hansen, Vice President of Engineering for Privacy, Safety, and Security 
Should companies be responsible for cyberattacks? The U.S. government thinks so ‚Äì and frankly, we agree. 
Jen Easterly and Eric Goldstein of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency at the Department of Homeland Security planted a flag in the sand:  
     ‚ÄúThe incentives for developing and selling technology have eclipsed customer safety in importance. [‚Ä¶] Americans‚Ä¶have unwittingly come to accept that it is normal for new software and devices to be indefensible by design. They accept products that are released to market with dozens, hundreds, or even thousands of defects. They accept that the cybersecurity ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The US Government says companies should take more responsibility for cyberattacks. We agree.

articles.description:
Posted by Oliver Chang, OSS-Fuzz team 
Since launching in 2016, Google's free OSS-Fuzz code testing service has helped get over 8800 vulnerabilities and 28,000 bugs fixed across 850 projects. Today, we‚Äôre happy to announce an expansion of our OSS-Fuzz Rewards Program, plus new features in OSS-Fuzz and our involvement in supporting academic fuzzing research. 
Refreshed OSS-Fuzz rewards 
  
The OSS-Fuzz project's purpose is to support the open source community in adopting fuzz testing, or fuzzing ‚Äî an automated code testing technique for uncovering bugs in software. In addition to the OSS-Fuzz service, which provides a free platform for continuous fuzzing to critical open source projects, we established an OSS-Fuzz Reward Program in 2017 as part of our wider Patch Rewards Program. 
We‚Äôve ope‚Ä¶
articles.title: Taking the next step: OSS-Fuzz in 2023

articles.description:
Sloth is a native Mac app that shows all open files, directories, sockets, pipes, and devices in use by all running processes on your system. This makes it easy to inspect which apps are using which files, etc.
lsof is powerful, but I use it infrequently and its CLI is inscrutable. That‚Äôs a perfect setup for a GUI like this.

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A nice Mac GUI for `lsof`

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Nikola ƒêuza lays out a way you can customize your README to stand out from the crowd:
GitHub supports adding HTML in Markdown, but it is pretty aggressive when removing HTML that can be potentially dangerous to users. Things like scripts, iframes, and similar will get removed or ‚Äúsilenced‚Äù to avoid malicious content from being served to users.
Luckily, there‚Äôs one way to sneak in some HTML (or a web page) inside the README. You can do it via SVG and foreignObject SVG element.

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Sneaking custom HTML & CSS in to your GitHub README

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Anybody following our news and/or podcast feeds for a bit already know of SQLite and have likely used it and continue to use it, but for those just joining us, here‚Äôs yet another dev with effusive praise for the little database engine that could:
SQLite is one of those projects that I wish I had known about long before I did. I had heard about it, but for many years I never thought about taking a serious look at it because I was under the false impression that is was a tiny database only useful for personal address books and small embedded devices.
I highly recommend you take a look at SQLite!
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: SQLite the only database you will ever need in most cases

articles.description:
Tim McNamara is known as New Zealand‚Äôs Rust guy. He is the author of Rust in Action, and also a Senior Software Engineer at AWS, where he helps other builders with all things Rust.
The main reason why Gerhard is intrigued by Rust is the incredible resource frugality. Fewer CPUs means less energy used, which is good for the planet, and good for the monthly bill. This becomes most noticeable at Amazon‚Äôs scale, when S3, Lambda, CloudFront and other services start adding Rust components.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Rust and Haskell don‚Äôt shy away from powerful features. As a result, both languages have steep learning curves when compared with other languages. Trying to learn Rust or Haskell can be frustrating, especially in the first couple of months.
But if you already know Rust, you have a head start with Haskell; and vice versa.
In this article, we want to show how knowledge of one of these languages can help you get up to speed with another.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Rust vs. Haskell

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
In a post about overestimating our short-term ability and underestimate our long-term ability, Paavan drops this nugget:
It‚Äôs important to recognise the value of quantity over quality. This is best illustrated by an anecdote that I first heard from Kevin Cannon at PUSH Conference: a potter who spends time making 100 vases will end up with one that‚Äôs better quality than if they spent the same amount of time trying to just make 1 perfect vase. So, while quality is obviously important, focussing on quantity at the start of a creative journey is the way to get there.
I‚Äôve never heard that anecdote before, but I absolutely love the truth it so clearly represents.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The value of quantity over quality

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Lucas F. Costa:
In this blog post, I‚Äôll elucidate why backlogs exist and why they never shrink. Then, I‚Äôll expound on why they‚Äôre useless and harmful. Finally, I‚Äôll demonstrate how one can work without a backlog and explain why it‚Äôs much more productive to do so.
I agree whole heartedly with his ‚Äúwhy they never shrink‚Äù logic, but I‚Äôm not willing to say that makes them ‚Äúuseless and harmful.‚Äù I‚Äôm not sure Lucas even believes that, since his advice of what to do instead at the end of the post boils down to ‚Äúkeep a short backlog.‚Äù
Still, I enjoy Lucas‚Äôs thought process and you might too. Recommended reading.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Why backlogs are useless, why they never shrink, and what to do instead

SELECT * FROM google.compute.instances 
WHERE zone = 'australia-southeast1-b' 
AND project = 'my-project';

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
This short piece by Jim Nielsen resonated with me (much like Manu‚Äôs post resonated with Jim). He says:
I like this idea of beginning to notice and bring attention to people or creative works that intentionally bring closure, even when you‚Äôre left wanting a little more.
When it comes to open source software, people often see a lack of activity and proclaim that a project is unmaintained. Sometimes that‚Äôs true, but sometimes the project is merely finished, and that‚Äôs okay. In fact, it‚Äôs better than okay. It‚Äôs downright successful.
There‚Äôs a big difference between quitting and finishing. Quitting is in the realm of failure, but finishing is in the realm of success. The key is to define what finished means before you get there, lest you feel like you‚Äôre merely quitting.
The art of knowing when to quit? Sure. But how about the art of knowing how to finish?
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The art of knowing when to quit

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Creator Tyler Deitz says:
StreetPass is a browser extension that helps you find your people on Mastodon. It piggybacks off the way Mastodon handles decentralized identity verification and turns it into a simple discovery tool that recommends users based on the websites you visit! Available for Chrome and Firefox (soon Safari).
Discovery is one of the more challenging facets of federated social networking. It gets even more challenging now that Twitter‚Äôs API is getting paywall‚Äôd, so most of the free tools to port your Twitter social graph over to Mastodon will quit working. I expect more tools like StreetPass to pop up in the coming days as the Fediverse seems to be capturing that hacker spirit Twitter once embraced.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: StreetPass: Find your people on Mastodon

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
What‚Äôs old is new cool again. Here‚Äôs Andy Jiang, writing on Deno‚Äôs blog:
In the past 10 years, the median size for a desktop webpage has gone from 468 KB to 2284 KB, a 388.3% increase. For mobile, this jump is even more staggering ‚Äî 145 KB to 2010 KB ‚Äî a whopping 1288.1% increase.
That‚Äôs a lot of weight to ship over a network, especially for mobile. As a result, users experience terrible UX, slow loading times, and a lack of interactivity until everything is rendered. But all that code is necessary to make our sites work the way we want.
This is the problem with being a frontend dev today. What started out fun for frontend developers, building shit-hot sites with all the bells and whistles, has kinda turned into not fun. We‚Äôre now fighting different browsers to support, slow networks to ship code over, and intermittent, mobile connections. Supporting all these permutations is a giant headache.
How do we square this circle? By heading back to the server (Swiss basement not required).
He goes on to talk about isomorphic JavaScript frameworks and Deno‚Äôs offerings in this space. But hey, you don‚Äôt need all that fancy stuff to do SSR. All you need is a programming language that can render HTML (this is almost all languages) and a server‚Ä¶
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The future (and the past) of the web is server-side rendering

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Filippo Valsorda:
Last May I left my job on the Go team at Google to experiment with more sustainable paths for open-source maintainers. I held on to my various maintainer hats (Go cryptography, transparency tooling, age, mkcert, yubikey-agent‚Ä¶), iterated on the model since September, and I‚Äôm happy to report that I am now a full-time independent open-source maintainer.
People like Filippo are still (unfortunately) the exception, not the rule. BUT! I‚Äôll celebrate every time an open source maintainer makes it to the promised land, hopefully paving the way for others to follow after.
I‚Äôm sharing details about my progress to hopefully popularize the model, and eventually help other maintainers adopt it, although I‚Äôm not quite ready to recommend anyone else drop everything to try this just yet.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: I‚Äôm now a full-time professional open source maintainer

Learning Kubernetes can seem overwhelming. It‚Äôs a complex container orchestration system, that has a steep learning curve. But with the right roadmap and understanding of the foundational concepts, it‚Äôs something that any developer or ops person can learn.
In this Kubernetes learning roadmap, I have added prerequisites and complete Kubernetes learning path covering basic to advanced Kubernetes concepts.

articles.description:
In our ops & infra world, we learn to optimise for redundancy, for mean time to recovery and for graceful degradation. We instinctively recognise single points of failure, and try to mitigate the risks associated with them.
For some years now, Daniel Vassallo has been doing the same, but in the context of life & work. Daniel talks about the role of randomness, about learning from small wins & about optimising for a lifestyle that matches your true preferences,. Apparently, ideas too should be treated like cattle, not pets.

While playing with the SQLite vs Filesystem benchmark, I became intrigued by how the cache between the two approaches behaved.  That led me to discover a super exciting tool called vmtouch, which allows you to interact with the Operating System page cache and do some performance debugging.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Richard MacManus from The New Stack spoke with Netlify CEO Matt Biilmann about the deal and their new catchphrase: ‚Äúcomposable architectures‚Äù
Biilmann described it as a ‚Äúchange away from monolithic solutions,‚Äù citing a couple of examples: Adobe Experience Manager ‚Äúas the DXP [digital experience platform] system for all your web productions‚Äù and Drupal ‚Äúas the core engine that both powers the backend and the frontend of your site, the business logic and the UI layer, and so on.‚Äù He argues that these types of ‚Äúmonolithic‚Äù solutions can ‚Äústart to feel very legacy and very dated.‚Äù
I‚Äôm not sure if ‚Äúcomposable architectures‚Äù will stick, but they sure did a good job of making ‚Äújamstack‚Äù a thing, so time will tell on that.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Netlify acquires Gatsby

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Greg Schier from Railway:
The theory goes that if you ship code on Friday you‚Äôll inevitably be working Saturday to fix what you broke. This makes logical sense; software is messy and mistakes are unavoidable.
But no, shipping code on Friday isn‚Äôt bad. At least, it doesn‚Äôt have to be.
The key to their success is confidence, which comes from having a solid deployment pipeline and shipping through it often. Gerhard Lazu hit that nail on the head in this short clip as well.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Why we ship the most code on Friday

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Bryan Braun reflects on years of pairing:
I‚Äôve pair-programmed in a lot of different situations. I‚Äôve been the junior developer who needed to be unblocked. I‚Äôve been the new team member, being onboarded to a new codebase. I‚Äôve paired with peers for knowledge-sharing and productivity. And I‚Äôve been the senior dev.
He goes on to say that it‚Äôs easy to put a pairing session on rails to avoid embarrassment, but:
When I think back, my favorite pair-programming sessions were the one where things went wrong. These were the moments that taught me what being a programmer is all about. What do you do when you don‚Äôt know what to do? How do you break down a new problem? What tools do you reach for? When do you abandon your current approach? These are things you can‚Äôt learn from a blog post.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The best part of pair programming is when things go wrong

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Robin Linacre:
SQL should be the first option considered for new data engineering work. It‚Äôs robust, fast, future-proof and testable. With a bit of care, it‚Äôs clear and readable. A new SQL engine - DuckDB - makes SQL competitive with other high performance dataframe libraries, making SQL a good candidate for data of all sizes.
You can make a similar argument for SQL that Gary Bernhardt made for Vim. Here‚Äôs Gary on Vim, run your own s/Vim/SQL/g filter on this as you read it:
‚Ä¶just for me, 15 years; at the beginning of that time, TextMate was just becoming popular. Then it was Sublime Text was cool. Then Atom was cool. Then VS Code was cool. A lot of people switched between two of those, three of those, maybe all four of those, and that whole time I was just getting better and better and better at Vim‚Ä¶ And you multiply that out by the length of a career, you use Vim for 40 years - you‚Äôre gonna be so good at it by the end, and it‚Äôs still gonna be totally relevant, I think.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: SQL should be your default choice for data engineering pipelines

articles.description:
An opinionated rant to accompany your Monday morning coffee:
When you work with a format as complex as yaml, it is difficult to be aware of all the features and subtle behaviors it has. There is an entire website dedicated to picking one of the 63 different multi-line string syntaxes. This means that it can be very difficult for a human to predict how a particular document will parse. Let‚Äôs look an example to highlight this‚Ä¶
Discuss on Changelog News

We talk COBOL and the state of education and opportunities around that language. We cover the state-of-the-art in Mainframe land, System Z, Linux on Mainframe, and more.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Chip Huyen:
When we actively hire, our startup gets 150 - 200 applications each month. I read every single one of them. Sometimes, I‚Äôd talk to a candidate and see that what we perceived as their strongest aspects actually weren‚Äôt included in their resume. Occasionally, a candidate would tell me that they didn‚Äôt expect their resume to still be screened by humans ‚Äì had they known, they would have written their resume differently.
The resume evaluation process is pretty much a black box for most candidates. And it is so because few hiring managers have publicly discussed this. I thought I should start the conversation.
Chip‚Äôs team mostly hires for infra and ML roles, so some of the advice here will be catered towards those positions. Still, if you‚Äôre on the job market you‚Äôd be well-served by spending 15-20 minutes reading this post and tweaking your resume where applicable.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: What we look for in a resume

ZITADEL has a really interesting workload that is both CPU intensive and latency sensitive. On top of this, their users are global, and traffic is bursty. Florian talks about how they evaluated AWS, GCP & Azure before they settled on the platform that met their requirements.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
I‚Äôm currently working at a top tier investment bank as a software engineer. I‚Äôm an insignificant cog in a machine that skims the cream from the milk. I‚Äôm earning the most money I‚Äôve ever made and yet I‚Äôm the least fulfilled I‚Äôve ever been.
Right now in the UK and across the world, things are uncertain. Companies are laying workers off, there‚Äôs a cost of living and energy crisis. I‚Äôm excruciatingly lucky to have been in the right place at the right time to develop the skillset I‚Äôve got. In times like these every signal is telling me to stay on the path I‚Äôm on, enjoying the comfort and safety of a high paying job.
I‚Äôm not going to listen. I‚Äôm quitting and I‚Äôm leaving this place. I‚Äôll see you in the mountains.
After this post blew up, Se√°n wrote a follow-up on what quitting the rat race means to him.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Se√°n Barry is quitting the rat race

articles.author: Adam Stacoviak
articles.description:
Yup, that Neon. Congrats to Nikita and team for this big win.
Databases and web apps go together like peanut butter and jelly. In a word, they‚Äôre inseparable. And despite all the amazing innovations in NoSQL data stores, often a good old relational database is the most reliable tool for the job.
We want to make it completely seamless to develop applications that need databases on Replit. Starting today, you can create and instantly begin to use PostgreSQL databases from within the Replit workspace.
The fine print.
Under the hood, this product is powered by our friends at Neon who have created a lightning-fast serverless database. The database will go to sleep after 5 minutes of inactivity. Most clients should handle the reconnection seamlessly.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Neon is powering Replit's serverless Postgres

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
This is a Pythonic wrapper around stable diffusion with image editing by InstructPix2Pix. The four images featured below (top) are generated by the following command:
imagine "a scenic landscape" "a photo of a dog" "photo of a fruit bowl" "portrait photo of a freckled woman"

Then they are edited (bottom) with the following commands:
>> aimg edit scenic_landscape.jpg "make it winter" --prompt-strength 20
>> aimg edit dog.jpg "make the dog red" --prompt-strength 5
>> aimg edit bowl_of_fruit.jpg "replace the fruit with strawberries"
>> aimg edit freckled_woman.jpg "make her a cyborg" --prompt-strength 13


Discuss on Changelog News

articles.author: James Graham
articles.description:
Interop 2022 showed significant improvements in the interoperability of multiple platform features, along with several cross-browser investigations that looked into complex, under-specified, areas of the platform where interoperability has been difficult to achieve. Building on this, we're pleased to announce Interop 2023, the next iteration of the Interop project.
The post Announcing Interop 2023 appeared first on Mozilla Hacks - the Web developer blog.
articles.title: Announcing Interop 2023

articles.author: James Graham
articles.description:
Last March we announced the Interop 2022 project, a collaboration between Apple, Bocoup, Google, Igalia, Microsoft, and Mozilla to improve the quality and consistency of their implementations of the web platform.
Now that it's 2023 and we're deep into preparations for the next iteration of Interop, it's a good time to reflect on how the first year of Interop has gone.
The post Interop 2022: Outcomes appeared first on Mozilla Hacks - the Web developer blog.
articles.title: Interop 2022: Outcomes
